results.title: ‘Moonage Daydream’ Review: David Bowie’s Sound and Vision
results.abstract: Brett Morgen’s new documentary about the singer uses archival material, not talking heads. But the film is more séance than biography.

multimedia.caption: David Bowie as seen in “Moonage Daydream.” Bowie himself seems to supply the film’s narration, via the director Brett Morgen’s dexterous editing.
David Bowie as seen in “Moonage Daydream.” Bowie himself seems to supply the film’s narration, via the director Brett Morgen’s dexterous editing.

results.abstract: Unraveling a murder case backstage at a Christie play in 1950s London.

results.title: God Loves a Show: Religious Satires Reveal the Art of Acting Faithful
results.abstract: In films like “Honk for Jesus. Save Your Soul” and shows like “The Righteous Gemstones,” pageantry is the top priority.

results.title: To Deal With Film Festival Pressure, Sarah Polley Heads for the Hills
results.abstract: Hiking helped the actress-turned-auteur as she premiered her buzzy drama “Women Talking” in Telluride and Toronto.

multimedia.caption: Sarah Polley at the Toronto premiere of her drama.
Sarah Polley at the Toronto premiere of her drama.

results.title: Godard Taught Me How to Watch Cinema, Even as He Kept Reinventing It
results.abstract: Jean-Luc Godard was a prophet of film’s future as an art form, layering images and sound that the body could sink into and the mind could puzzle through.

multimedia.caption: Isabelle Huppert in “Every Man for Himself,” Jean-Luc Godard’s 1980 return to form.
Isabelle Huppert in “Every Man for Himself,” Jean-Luc Godard’s 1980 return to form.
Isabelle Huppert in “Every Man for Himself,” Jean-Luc Godard’s 1980 return to form.

results.title: Jean-Luc Godard, 91, Is Dead; Bold Director Shaped French New Wave
results.abstract: The Franco-Swiss filmmaker and provocateur radically rethought motion pictures and left a lasting influence on the medium.
results.byline: By Dave Kehr and Jonathan Kandell

multimedia.caption: Jean-Luc Godard in 1964. “I have always confused cinema with life,” he said. “To me life is just part of films.”
Jean-Luc Godard in 1964. “I have always confused cinema with life,” he said. “To me life is just part of films.”
Jean-Luc Godard in 1964. “I have always confused cinema with life,” he said. “To me life is just part of films.”

results.title: ‘Heathers: The Musical’ Review: For the Cliques
results.abstract: This musical may lack the 1989 movie’s nihilism, but the gags still work and the songs are great — who are we to quibble?

multimedia.caption: From left, Teleri Hughes, Vivian Panka and Maddison Firth in “Heathers: The Musical.”

results.title: ‘Terra Femme’ Review: How Women Have Seen the World
results.abstract: An assemblage of travelogues shot by women from the 1920s through the 1950s, this experimental essay film can be seen with either live or prerecorded narration.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “Terra Femme,” a travelogue film directed by Courtney Stephens that includes footage going back to the 1920s.
A scene from “Terra Femme,” a travelogue film directed by Courtney Stephens that includes footage going back to the 1920s.

results.title: ‘Confess, Fletch’ Review: Solving a Crime, Eventually
results.abstract: Jon Hamm bops along amiably enough as the carefree, wiseacre detective once played by Chevy Chase.

results.title: The Eight Film Festival Movies That Got the Biggest Awards Boost

results.title: ‘God’s Country’ Review: A Solitary Woman Isn’t Left Alone for Long
results.abstract: In this simmering thriller, Thandiwe Newton plays a professor in rural Montana who confronts two hunters who say they’re just passing through.

multimedia.caption: In “God’s Country,” Thandiwe Newton conveys a subtle melancholy that seems to have settled on her like a heavy blanket.
In “God’s Country,” Thandiwe Newton conveys a subtle melancholy that seems to have settled on her like a heavy blanket.
In “God’s Country,” Thandiwe Newton conveys a subtle melancholy that seems to have settled on her like a heavy blanket.

results.title: ‘The Silent Twins’ Review: Keeping the World at Bay
results.abstract: A beguiling look at the complicated story of the real-life twins June and Jennifer Gibbons, who lived in a mental institution for over a decade.

multimedia.caption: Tamara Lawrance, left, and Letitia Wright in “The Silent Twins.”
Tamara Lawrance, left, and Letitia Wright in “The Silent Twins.”
Tamara Lawrance, left, and Letitia Wright in “The Silent Twins.”

results.title: ‘The Woman King’ Review: She Slays
results.abstract: Viola Davis leads a strong cast into battle in an epic from Gina Prince-Bythewood, inspired by real women warriors.

multimedia.caption: In “The Woman King,” Viola Davis leads the women warriors of Dahomey, a real regiment in 19th-century Africa whose exact origins remain obscured by tribal myths and oral traditions.
In “The Woman King,” Viola Davis leads the women warriors of Dahomey, a real regiment in 19th-century Africa whose exact origins remain obscured by tribal myths and oral traditions.

results.title: With an Israeli Superhero, Marvel Wades Into an Intractable Conflict
results.abstract: The studio has angered many Palestinians and their supporters by casting the actress Shira Haas to play Sabra, a mutant Mossad agent, in a “Captain America” movie.

results.title: Jokes + Exasperation + Subtext = a New York Club Comic on the Rise

results.title: A New Ariel Inspires Joy for Young Black Girls: ‘She Looks Like Me’
results.abstract: Disney has had only one prominent Black princess. A new version of “The Little Mermaid” starring Halle Bailey is changing that, much to the delight of Black children and their parents.

results.title: Opening Old Wounds as the Man Who Warned About the Holocaust
results.abstract: In the solo play “Remember This,” David Strathairn portrays Jan Karski, a witness to the Nazi genocide during World War II.

results.title: Marsha Hunt, Actress Turned Activist, Is Dead at 104
results.abstract: She seemed well on her way to stardom until her career was derailed by the Hollywood blacklist. She then turned her attention to social causes.

multimedia.caption: The actress Marsha Hunt in an undated photo. Early in her career, she was one of the busiest and most versatile actresses in Hollywood.

results.abstract: At the Toronto premiere, she spoke of playing a homophobic mother as “the challenge of a lifetime” because it represents everything she stands against in reality.
